I thought they were ALL too dry, though the third one at least had a little broth. What these college kids seem to miss is that Ramen is a Japanese noodle SOUP; it's supposed to have broth. It's not pasta, where you cook the pasta then drain it. And the one girl first complains the Ramen is too salty, then says it has no flavor; the flavor (including salt) is in the packet that all Ramen comes with.  Ramen is very basic, and it's meant to be doctored.    -Always add an egg, allowed to poach in the liquid.    -Add vegetables to the water as you heat it to boil, before adding the noodles or the seasoning.    -Add other protein, like chicken shreds, shrimp, thin-sliced beef or pork.  Just pick up small quantities of fresh ingredients from a salad bar and use them over the course of the week, daily using to make your Ramen better. By varying the ingredients, the Ramen will taste a little different each day while not coasting much. Also, you don't need much shrimp for Ramen; when you pick up a $5 pack of cooked shrimp, just save 2 or 3 shrimp per Ramen you want to add it to. If you freeze them in a ziplock, you can pull a couple out whenever you want some in your Ramen.  What I like are tiny broccoli florets, thin carrot 'coins' (if you notch the edges, they look like flowers), napa cabbage, sliced mushrooms, snow peas, shrimp, the seasoning packet, the noodles, and a raw egg (the white allowed to cook, the yolk partly-cooked). Then, before serving, a handful of chopped green onions. But you need enough water to start, just to get the broth for your soup.

I make the best Ramen.  My daughter loves it so much that she asked me for the recipe.  I boil mine until they're just about done and then strain them.   I put them back into the pot with the seasoning, butter and milk on medium heat.  Then I add cheese and basically pick whatever meat depending on which kind of Ramen, be it beef, chicken or shrimp.  Stir it all up, and when the cheese is melted, serve it up!  It's absolutely delicious.  Better than some noodles I've bought in restaurants.

Okay, cool ramen. But here is one superior: Chicken flavoured instant ramen Dark soy sauce  bacon strips Boiled eggs (boiled for around 5-7 minute, based on your preference) Flaky sea salt  Minced Garlic Sesame oil Chopped green onions You wont get better instructions than these, thats just how it is: Put the ramen with the seasoning package in a bowl, cover with 1/2 cup of boiling water, cover with a plate and let steep Fill a cup with the desired amount of garlic and green onions, this will be your aromatic oil Now cook your bacon strips untill crispy Pour the hot fat in the cup with aromatics, cover and let it sit for a while Now take a look at your delicious bowl of ramen and add in dark soy sauce, you can also add black pepper if you want Add in your bacon, the eggs that have been cut in half, and sprinkle some flaky salt on your eggs (just a bit) Uncover the aromatic oil and add in a bit of sesame oil (preferably toasted) Pour a bit of that liquid flavor in your bowl and have a nice meal NOTE: feel free to add anything, for example MSG if you'd like, I'll be glad if you sent a modified recipe in the replies

all three of the ramens look wrong, as someone who eats authentic Japanese ramen very often and has seen documentaries about it; no broth, noodles not wet enough (ramen is literally noodles in a massive bowl of broth soup), it often includes things like spring onion, seaweed, greens, an egg, bamboo shoots, spice (if oyu want it hot), and then meat, veg or seafood. The broth is the part that instant ramen cannot do properly...broth takes days. IMO the last one was the only one even CLOSE to Ramen...becuse it had oriental flavours.

Hi my name is oluwowoyameyoluawowayoyağŸ˜Š Hi my names MarcusğŸ˜
Yea Ramen is supposed to have broth, and looks like she has the correct amount, enough to keep noodles moist but it was not drowning. For color i would've added green onions or cilantro. Also for color i do add about 1/2 to 3/4 of the seasoning packet while cooking and add the rest after you served and mix. I also add egg and the meat that it is flavored(except chili flavor i usually ass beef to that). Trust ramen you can experiment but make sure you have broth otherwise it isnt ramen.
Okay okay let me give some real advice about making decent broke ramen:  If you have at least a mini fridge/freezer, get some eggs, get a package of sliced ham, and a frozen bag of mixed veggies. If you're just cooking for you these should last several meals. Boil the eggs with salt for 7-8 minutes then put in ice water for perfect jammy medium eggs. Then boil some water for the noodles and while cooking them add the frozen vegetables. Take 1-2 slices of ham and slice it extra into bite size strips. Then once the noodles n veggies are boiled, add the seasoning, boiled eggs n ham. Maybe add sriracha if you want extra spice. Enjoy.

this is js a cheap ramen w things that YOu have/can get for a low price. js sum ingredients for how I like my ramen, but don't listen to my broke ass </3  ramen 12 pack ($3) soy sauce (4-8 bucks depending on where you get it, but some of the cheap ones r good yet the others r not. don't get fooled luvs) minced garlic in a jar < mincing garlic yourself- $1 (it's cheaper to get the garlic as it is, just so you don't waste money on a couple of garlics in a jar even tho u js using it for a couple of meals.) seasoning cubes-$2 (LIFE CHANGER. it fr tastes good most of the times depending on which flavor you get. for me, chicken is the best one since you could deffo taste all the flavor packed inside of it.) controversial, but great value seasonings r an easy price and good if you use your cards right when cooking. ik this ain't a full ass meal but this is js ideas on what to get for cheap. but reminder for y'all, most people can get all this sh and yet it still taste horrible. at least learn how to use yo seasonings right so it tastes good ig  ğŸ’€

My go to college ramen is mama brand. They're from thai land and its aboutnthe same price as top ramen or maruchan, but the flavors ans everything are WAY better. Throw some tuna or chicken in there, hit it with a bit of sauce (depends on how i'm feeling. Sometimes it just some sriracha, sometikes its my mom's dumpling sauce if i'm feeling zesty.) Crack and egg into it right after you remove it from heat and let the residual heat cook the egg while you stir it. Garnish with ginger, garlic, and green onion, and hitnitnwith a tiny bit more sesame seed oil. Flavor town, my friends. All for about a dollar

all i eat everyday is plain ramen with the seasoning packet all 3 look better than what i make tbh
69
Cook your ramen like you would and after it gets done crack an egg into it turn off the heat and cover the egg with noodles set a timer for 3 mins. While you are waiting for the egg to cook put chili paste garlic the white part of green onions and the seasoning packet in a non stick pan on medium low heat let it cook for about 15 seconds then add any type of cheese once the cheese starts to stick to the pan add milk slowly while mixing until the consistency is that of a thick sauce. By this time the egg should be done cooking. Take the egg out of the ramen and put the ramen in the sauce pan without the broth and mix the sauce in. Put the ramen in a bowl and while you wait for it to cool fry some ham once the ham is done place the ham on one side of the bowl. Cut open the egg and place it on the other side. Then sprinkle the green parts of green onion in the middle and enjoy  There are also different ways you can cook the egg, soft boiled, sunny side up/fried, or just crack it in and stir it in

I make my ramen and while it's cooking I put the seasoning packet in the bowl im gonna use and then also add a spoon full of some home made chili oil mmmmm that shit is good af and then I will make me two burger patties and when the ramen is done I pour about three spoon fulls of water from the ramen into the bowl with the chili oil and seasoning and stir it in nicely and then drain the rest of the water and put the noodles into the bowl mix it well so the flavor gets into the noodles and then add the burgers on top if you fill your bowl even half way up with the water then you're making ramen a lot worse than it has to be lmao.  to clarify about half of the water she had in her ramen is about what you want but the girl olu I knew from the start her dish was gonna be trash "I cook with seasonings they probably never even heard of" it's not the fucking 1920's we have the internet they probably have a broader understanding of seasoning than she does that girl needs an ego check.

If you like cheese, try this:  -1 packet of creamy chicken ramen noodles (Cook for 4.5 minutes in microwave without seasoning, with water then drain)  -Milk (after noodles are drained add desired amount of milk and seasoning packet, and stir in)  -add a slice of American cheese on top and add some hotdogs diced (you can add a squirt of ranch too for extra creaminess)!  Put in the microwave for another :30 seconds to 1:00 minute and enjoy.

This is how I make shin ramen as an 11 year old:   Step 1. Get a pot with water and let it boil   Step 2. When the water starts boiling add your ramen   Step 3. Halfway through the cooking process put the seasoning packet (obviously use something to mix)  Step 4. Right before itâ€™s almost done get cheese (any kind u want) and put a lot over your ramen DONT MIX IT!  Step 5. Get a lid and cover the ramen   Step 6. Set it to the side until the cheese is all melted ğŸ˜‹  Step 7. Add any other toppings u want I like to put boiled eggs with mine   Step 8. Enjoy ğŸ˜Š â¤

Yes, there are many  types of ramen or at least noodles. I live in Asia, and you will find dry ramen as commonly as soup based ramen. There are even snacks where people prefer to just break then noodles into pieces in the bag and add the seasoning and eat it like chips (Mamee noodles). As much as I love both dry and soup, dry does not mean sand dry! It still has a glossy sauce to it and it aint supposed to clump up like the noodles shown in this video! It is very entertaining to see how students put a twist to their budget noodles. Cheetah print probably had an acquired tastebud from where shes from (im assuming nigeria from the seasonings) and im not sure but maybe if they have noodles they eat it dry? Not sure then again im lazy to do research. In american culture when I visit all I can think of for soup is tomato soup lmao, and there are sure no noodles in there! But pasta is more common right? Pasta is considered "dry" but cheese, milk, and eggs are suuuper expensive right now! Like Im hoping the ramen packets you buy come with the seasonings already right?? not just the pure noodles. just cook it, leave the water in, and just pour inthe seasonings and mix! add a egg in the process, let it cook but not fully harden. You got protein and flavour! If you happen to like it dry you can use the noodle water to cook some veggies like mini bok choy, saves water! its just startchy water. Then you can use the vegtable water once cooled down to water plants or something. I reccomend you dont add all seasoning though because its really really not good for you. i know we all know, but i reccomend you dont.  anyway, safe cooking!   (also, try instant udon it lighter and less salty for me)

How do none of these people know ramen is supposed to have broth.  This is my ramen recipe if anyone wants to try:  Broth: boil water and add 1-3 tsp of old bay seasoning and add the flavor seasoning packet. Then add your ramen in, the reason you add the seasoning in first is to make sure that the ramen absorbs all of the flavor. Btw, make sure that the water only just covers the ramen so as to avoid too much broth and the need to remove some because broth is flavor.  Then make two eggs with salt and pepper, sunny side up and covered to cook the top with steam, and cook it in oil, only remove once the top is white and not like jelly but make sure the yolks are still runny.  After chop up some scallions or Chinese chives and add them in, make sure the are thin to maximize surface area and therefore flavor.   Drizzle sriracha over the egg but donâ€™t add too much because too much spice dulls overall flavor.  And for the sauce: mix 1 part honey, 1 part sesame oil, and 3 parts soy sauce, feel free to add chili oil as well for more flavor.

I didn't know Ramen can be dry. I'm from Asia, and Ramen is a type of noodle soup in Japan. It's the name of the dish. It has to be in a broth/soup. If it's not, it's an entire different noodle dish with different name. The guy even mocked that the noodles are swimming in those tiny amount of broth and called it a flood or tsunami? I would call those Ramen water shortage, drought calamity, and desert dry. There are thousands of different stirfried noodles in Asia, and noodle dish without broth, or sauce, and none are called Ramen. That includes instant noodles or noodle packet. It indicates if it has to be dry or with broth unless you bought the packed instant cooking noodles. Still, it's not called Ramen. Maybe in the west they think instant cooking noodles is called Ramen. That's like saying all Pasta is just Spaghetti in tomato Sauce.

nah bro they ainâ€™t doing this right ğŸ˜­this is the ramen I made when I didnâ€™t have a lot of money: Put enough water in a pot to make a pool for the noodles  Wait till it boils Boil the noodles for 5 mins and add the seasoning  Drain the noodles but leave a little bit of water left. On low heat stir fry the noodles with hot sauce until sauce is mixed in ( preferably buldak sauce)  Transfer to a bowl and while itâ€™s still hot, add cheese and mix it in. If you want it to be creamier, add an egg yolk and mix it in. Add green onions and serve  Additional ingredient/serving options: Spam, Seaweed, rice, Kimchi, Ricecakes, Chicken ( Iâ€™ll do these ingredients once in a while if iâ€™m feeling fancy ) Itâ€™s so good and filling, and it only costs a few dollars to make

I would love to have people try my version. I cook it in the microwave and drain it until there's about an inch of water left at the bottom. Then I use the whole packet of chicken flavoring but others could use half if they don't like the saltiness. I then add soy sauce, a little lime juice, and a LOT of green chili hot sauce. Sriracha is also really good! Sometimes if I'm really hungry I'll make two packs, one chicken and one beef, and mix them together.

Man I was a broke ass college student too and I got good at making ramen, cheap. Instant ones (Usually a few cents per packet) -throw out that nasty flavor packet- chicken or veggie broth which is around $1-3 in the two States I've lived. I'd buy a few green onions which are usually around .33cents for like 4-5 of them. If I had a few dollars to spare, a bit of ginger and if I had eggs-I'd hard boil one.  Usually spend around $5-$7 per half a week. SO around $14 at best the entire week.  Sometimes less because I'd hunt down those deals. But obviously, prices will depend on where you live and not everything is as cheap all the time. Still... I may have lost a lot of weight then but at least I survived.  Edit: Ironically, I was in culinary school lol Also forgot to say... what in the dry ass ramen is that? Whyyyy were they so dry? Thats not ramen anymore.

Secret tip to the broke college kids out there. Thereâ€™s a sauce called â€˜tian mian jiangâ€™ which translates to â€˜sweet noodle sauceâ€™ that is used in Asian cooking and a lot of dry ramens to give food a dark color and saltiness like soy sauce that also adds a tiny bit of sweetness and umami. Itâ€™s the key ingredient to jiajiang noodle or the â€˜Korean fireâ€™ Samyang noodle we all know and love. For the people out there trying to make their own noodles from scratch this is something worth playing around with.

All of these people are being way too extra. First of all, the ramen is the broth, not the noodles so I would classify most of these as just noodles, definitely not ramen. Second of all, draining the broth out is like taking all the fat out of a steak, it just doesn't make any type of sense. And third of all, if you're so broke, you shouldn't be adding shrimp to your bland ass noodles and you should be drinking the broth because it still has nutritious value. If you want to make your cup noodles taste better, add a hard/soft boiled egg to it (I like hard boiled because I like the texture better). And if that won't satisfy you, find random stuff in your fridge that could work. You could add bacon, collard greens, maybe some seaweed or maybe even some mushrooms (don't knock it until you try it). But always remember, if you're so broke you rely on cup noodles, don't throw away the broth.

I make my ramen soup style with mirin, Thai red curry paste, and a half tablespoon of sesame oil in the broth. Then I add fresh mung beans, shiitake mushrooms, green onion, a bit of fresh ginger, and crushed red pepper. Shrimp is good if you have it, but it definitely doesnâ€™t need it. A soft boiled egg is nice too. Some of those ingredients are a little pricey (mirin, sesame oil, curry paste), but once you have them, it lasts a while and it becomes part of a staple cheap meal. Garnish with Thai basil if you have it. ğŸ‘ŒğŸ½

Ramen can be broken up and ate like crunchy chips   Or u could add in an egg and slice of cheese in ramen noodles with some broth is yum   Try with some chili powder in it for a spicy kick   Try using 2 cups of water with some boulin cubes chicken or beef or a mix of the 2 for broth then add in some pickle juice and a diced pickle and a friend egg with cheese is yum   And to add on to that if u want Try steak em meat ,cheese onions and mix bell peppers with some mushrooms a died up pickles  and seasoning packet and a dash of horseradish sauce mixed it all together don't dump the broth its good and delicious could save it for next time u make ramen or drink it as a tasty snack tastes just like philly cheesesteak it's so extremely good and delicious   If u don't like the packet find a empty small container with Lid mix 1 tbs of onion powder garlic powder, minced dried onions ,chives celery seed ,kosher salt,  black pepper ,chicken and steak seasoning  lemon pepper, chili powder, paprika, jerky and mix everything together and add bout half of a tbsp to a tsp depending on what flavor u going for

Bro why's her. Name so long
I know ramen with broth is amazing but check this out.  1) Use Shin Ramyun (if you're okay with spice) and put the flavor packs in a bowl, also add minced garlic and some chopped green onions to the bowl. 2) While you cook the noodles in water also heat up a bit of vegetable or peanut oil in small pan. 3) Once noodles are soft and oil is fairly hot, pour the oil into the bowl that has your spices and mix it all together. 4) Once soft, put noodles only in the bowl (add a splash of the hot water) and mix it well so the spices get all over the noodles.   I started doing this after eating basic top ramen with the water and I honestly get so much more flavor out of the ramen this way. If you try it let me know what you think! ( I also add cayene powder, ginger powder, and smoked paprika to my spices along with a hardboiled egg to top it, but add or don't add whatever you like! Also pro tip: add a bit of soy sauce to the water cooking the noodles.)

Use the flavoring packet and add fresh tomato, onion and celery (along with maybe a mushroom or any herbs you may like), it's simple but flavorful.   Plain old flavor packet and water with noodles always felt a little salty, so when adding everything else, the packet seasons well. You can afford to use a little less water since the vegetables themselves have water, but the broth comes out tasty for instant ramen imo.  1 fresh tomato chopped into (maybe an inch?) pieces 1/4 to 1/2 an onion (also not necessarily diced, but pieces you're comfortable spooning or forking) 1-2 Celery sticks  Boil that for maybe 3-5 mins before adding noodles and flavor packet and cooking as directions indicate.

For any ramen in the microwave:  -Ramen pack in large bowl with too much water. -Into the microwave for 7 minutes. -Take it out at 3 minutes, and pour out enough water to be slightly above the ramen. - Mix in the seasoning packet and pot it back in the microwave for the last 3 minutes. - take out and stir   For shrimp flavor, add lime juice, old bay, and whatever hot product you want - for chicken, you can use adobo, lemon, and add sour cream to make it creamy - You cant go wrong with cayenne pepper

Personal struggle Ramen recipe: -package of ramen -beef jerky  -green onions -peanut butter -optional seasonings/toppings  Step one: Soak beef jerky for a minute, so you don't feel like you're chewing on an old boot. (Warning: Don't use slim jims, because they're ass, and you'll hate yourself for the attempt.)  Step 2: Once the jerky is a bit soft, shred it and put it in a bowl with the noodle block. Add enough water to steam the noodles and make the jerky tender.  Step 3: Add a teaspoon of peanut butter (weird, I know) to help everything adhere. Add seasoning packet.  Step three: Top with green onions. Add anything else you may desire. Soy sauce from that one time you ordered take-out, Sriracha that you borrowed from your roommate, more green onions because they're hella cheap (seriously, two bundles for a dollar)  and you can regrow the tops if you put them in a glass of water.  Step 4: Enjoy while watching Netflix. How can you afford Netflix? You can't, you stole the password from your parents.

The first time I ever ate ramen noodles was in the 70s while on vacation in Hawaii Theye were not served with liquid or as a soup. We feel in love with them they were hard to find in the state I live in and hadn't caught on yet but we would order them because they were so good.  We would drain the liguid off then relax them in cold water to stop the cooking  and add the seasoning, sesame oil, garlic, oyster sauce and garlic chili sauce like they did in Hawaii. For my ramen: I pour a little peanut oil in a pan Crush up my noodles a bit and add them to the peanut oil Brown them Add a little water Add some steak ums  Pour in ramen seasoning plus chili lime seasoning (tajin) Cook on high so the water evaporates at the same rate the "steak" is cooked" Possibly add some shrimp Evaporate all water before the noodles get too mushy RAMEN

Dr.Slone?
Keep the broth. And put a boiled egg. One egg costs like $0.17, and if you boil it first (then drain excess water, put in noodles & soup mix), then peel it and cut it in half, it makes the ramen look pro (like at a Ramen stand). I also keep a bag of frozen corn (dirt cheap), and throw a handful of that in there at the end. It cools the soup down, and corn is especially good in pork ramen. Even some green onions... $0.10 of onion per bowl. All said, you drop fifty cents of added ingredients per bowl and it's dynamite.

My favorite way to make ramen: Start with shrimp flavor ramen (Maruchan is the brand for me). I find it easier to dissolve the seasoning by doing it separately instead of in the pot with the noodles like the directions say. So empty the seasoning packet into the bowl you're going to use for eating the ramen. To the seasoning add Italian seasoning, garlic powder, ginger powder, and red pepper flakes to taste. The noodles could be boiling while you do this. No need to measure the water. Just enough to boil and have some left over. When the noodles are cooked, transfer some of the hot water to the bowl of seasoning to dissolve. Add as much or as little water as you like to make a broth. Drain the rest of the water from the noodles and mix them in the broth. Sprinkle a few drops of sesame oil and mix for an added layer of flavor. That's how I do it.

This hurts. As a broke asian, these recipes were surprisingly disappointing and I hope one day they can learn the ways of making real, tasty ramen. Whether you prefer the broth or not, struggle ramen can easily become a delicious, quality meal. For instance, the texture of the noodles looked strangley congealed, mushy and/or slimy.. they looked like it lacked spices and there's just much more that could have been added to get some cheap nutrition in (egg, vegetables, additional sauces). I'm not saying my ramen is the best and I'm sure they all have delicious recipes of their own, but holy shit they could really use some tips when it comes to making ramen.

I love oyster sauce in my ramen!! Also moooost of the time I dump 90% of the broth, add some sesame oil for slip, extra seasonings & some veggies if in the fridge.. ğŸ¤¤
I have three ways I make ramen so far and I'm just 14. Number 1 is soy sauce ramen; make beef ramen, drain the water, take a tbs of butter or margarine, add that in then mix, then get 5-10 splashes of soy sauce and mix. Number two is spicy chicken ramen; take some chicken ramen, boil some water, when the water starts to boil, add garlic season all, basil, pepper, and pork and poultry dry rub seasoning, then add your noodles, make sure to keep the broth for it is really good for you. Number three is Mac and cheese ramen with hotdogs, make normal chicken ramen, drain out the water, add two slices of American cheese or any sliced cheese, then add a pinch of grated cheddar cheese, then cook two hotdogs for 25 seconds each, put them in the bowl then mix and mix and mix until the cheese is mixed up well and the hotdogs are in chunks. Enjoy these.

What I learned from this video is there's a HUGE difference between being a 'broke' college student (a rich kid having to struggle temporarily for the first time) and a person who grew up poor. Poor people are grateful for food, would never be so rude when presented with it, throw it on the table, or spit it out of their mouth. And 2. Poor people are extremely creative with their struggle meals and will find ways to add nutrition in the cheapest way they can. SOUP.     soup /sup/ Noun Any of various dishes commonly made by combining LIQUIDS, such as water or stock with other ingredients, such as meat and vegetables, that contribute flavor and texture. "Pho is a traditional Vietnamese soup." A serving of such a dish, typically in a bowl. The liquid part of such a dish; the broth. Verb To feed: to provide with soup or a meal. To develop (film) in a (chemical) developing solution. Alternative form of sup

This is how I eat my ramen Ramen noodles  Cooked Shrimp Diced pepper Diced onion Scrambled egg Soy sauce   Heat half cup of water in microwave for 3 minutes Place noodles in bowl crushed or hole Add green peppers and onions to dry noodles Poor microwaved water over noodles and cover with lid Let' stand 5 minutes Drain all water but place in a cup to the side Add cooked shrimp and two scrambled eggs with noodles Add half packet of ramen seasoning in noodles Add remaining ramen seasoning in water that was drained earlier from the noodles Add half teaspoon soy sauce to noodles If you a person that likes broth in your noodles add as much ramen seasoned broth to the noodles Microwave one last time for 30 seconds Do not overcook noodles noodles will become really squishy noodle should be firm but not hard and able to stick to the wall I've been eating it this way all my life don't knock it till you try it

The only one who knows how to make ramen is Cheyenne. Geeze people, Ramen is supposed to have watery broth in it. "Too watery". Every Asian chef has to be cringing at this right now.    Marcus' ramen was not too bad considering he did everything right except for one thing which is the reason Cheyenne said that the texture of the noodles was wrong was because there was no _stock broth_ for the noodles to absorb the broth. Without the stock broth, the noodles can't absorb anything which is why the texture was all wrong.   50% watery broth (Asian stock), 50% rest meat (of your choice) and veggies along with spices and a boiled egg (optional). _That is real ramen_ Despite my praise to Cheyenne, I do have to critique her for one thing; she didn't add spring onions or green onions or simple chopped vegetables and scrambled egg to her ramen dish.

Ok to clear up some things, ramen is a soup dish. When you have no soup = noodle dish or stir=fry noodle dish. Don't say "buuttt samyang" First that is korean noodles and it's called ramyun. Its typically with a soup like shin ramyun or no soup like with samyang! Indomie is indonesian noodles so typically no soup.

Ramen is one of those things that I think everyone, literally every single person, likes it differently. The way I make ramen I absolutely love -- but I've never made ramen for someone else and had them enjoy it. And vice versa. I like my noodles pretty firm, so I usually only let the noodles boil for about two minutes, then rest on the counter in the bowl for a minute more. I usually mix in the seasoning packet to the water while the noodles are cooking, and then use just a bit of that broth in the noodles. Sometimes I'll add stuff like mushrooms and green onions. Also, my favorite -- a slice of good old American cheese melted in it. It makes it so oily and creamy and rich. Sometimes I might add a dash of something spicy if I'm using a beef or soy sauce flavor, but if I'm using chicken flavor? A splash of lemon juice and some black pepper.

And for broke college students: Ramen at Dollar General 1 dollar for 6  in a package, buy some dam frozen mixed veggies and get some chicken or pork( where you spend the most) throw that dang packet out of ramen package in bowl for later(stock) or in trash, contains way too much salt. Cook your meat in a pan browning it slightly, take the water and any spices you like and veg and add to meat turning down to simmer , cook noodles in microwave with water and drain when done. put cooked/drainednoodles in bowl and pour over hot saucepan withe all that goodness in to bowl over noodles and add hot sauce(Texas Pete or the like to top)

A dry instant ramen is like most uncomfortable way to eat ramen when you take a spoon of it you end up taking the whole bowl ok ok let me give a recipe there's nothing added just instant ramen  Ok first you need yippee mood Masala  noodles (don't add the mood Masala full if u don't like a lil burning sensation)  You need a cup of water  And boil the noodless as usual  But take the noodles out after like umm 50 sec(make sure to stir it)  Then pour it into your bowl (don't drain water)  Pour the Masala (the main Masala for the taste of the noodles and the mood masala for the broth)  Mix it and enjoy  The reason why I like this type it cooks very fast and it looks like a spring and it's very chewyyyyy so yeah

â€œWhy are the two people acting like itâ€™s not supposed to have water?â€ Perhaps because black people generally donâ€™t eat it as a soup? Itâ€™s a cultural preference - the water is drained and then itâ€™s typically eaten dry or near dry with only a tad bit of the â€œbrothâ€ remaining. Hence why they were both surprised to see an abundance of water or â€œsoupâ€. I think people tend to forget that cultural differences, in terms of how food is made and eaten, varies across the board or at least they donâ€™t know what to do when confronted with it. I.e. Growing up, my family and friends preferred method for cooking bacon was in the oven. Thatâ€™s how our parents taught us and that method was passed down from their parents and so forth and so on. I had no idea that bacon could be cooked or was cooked another way until I went to college and learned that most of my friends (who were white) cooked it in a pan on the stove. I was shooketh and so were they when they found out that I cooked it in the oven....  Respect each otherâ€™s differences. How to make packet ramen in a microwave and make it still taste good: Step 1: Get a bowl and take out the ramen out of the bag, and crush it in the bowl Step 2: Pour Water into bowl with ramen in it (Any Temperature) Step 3: Place bowl in microwave and set to 1:00 Step 4: Take out bowl and place plate on top of the bowl and place in microwave for 2:00 (To let the steam flow) Step 5: (The Bowl will be hot, so grab a rag and hold the plate.) If you donâ€™t like soup with your ramen just put the plate against the bowl and let the water spill out without spilling the ramen out. Step 6: Pour Flavor Packet and mix Step 7: Enjoy and make sure to blow your food because it will be hot!

Nobody cares but how I make my ramen noodles is.  1. I get chicken flavoring  2. Boil the water and put it in 3. Wait 4 Min 4. Put 1/4 seasoning in water for broth 5. Put 3/4 seasoning on it like a raft 6. Boil it for like 5 min 7. Drain most of the broth  8. Put little broth in the bowl 9. Put noodles in the bowl 10. Add siracha 11. Add 4 pepporoni's 12. Add pepper & Mix 13. Enjoy!

my ramen recipe Pork maruchan (i perfer top ramen but pork maruchan hits) medium boiled egg (medium= 5 minutes) Poke little holes into egg and marinate in soy sauce, sesame oil, korean chili paste, and little sugar) When the noodles r done add the powder then the egg with sriracha on top..mm bomb asf

As a certified poor college student and ramen connoisseur, the best technique for better noodles (cause theirs looked VERY dry other than the last girl)  is to with a stove: boil 2 cups of water and once a bit of steam is visible from the pan you put the noodles. Once it is bubbling (like, actually boiling) and the noodles have separated you insert the msg pack into it and spin it around a bit. Turn off the heat but leave the pan there and put a top on so that the noodles can become smoother and absorb just a bit of the soup. Monitor the noodles until it has gotten to your liking (I recommend around 5 min for the perfect texture)  I recommend fried egg and (cooked) spam on it (best combo)

Shrimp in the ramen wouldnt be cheap   Here are my ideas for cheap ramen Spicy ramen - grab a bowl put some szechuan sauce maybe a drop or 2 not much put water in the bowl stir add noodles microwave 60 seconds flip then 30 seconds  Soy ramen - same as spicy but after adding the szechuan add a little soy not much but enough to thinly color the bottom of the bowl  ... Wanna add a little something you can get a head of lettuce get a few pieces after the 60 second heat up add the lettuce under the ramen you flipped ... Bam simple easy cheap af while giving you some taste but everyones tastes are different and its good to experiment with what you like and honestly you dont have to go crazy with it for it to be good or spend too much (sauces are long term cheaper typically and can mask if you get a flavor you dont like as well I prefer chicken ramen to shrimp but shrimp ramen can be cheaper) ğŸ¤·

Here's how I were to make a broke ramen dish. Considering they used chicken and shrimp, I'll use anything less than that. Shrimp is at least $7 and chicken is at least $5 where I am. So my budget is $6. Eggs - $1.29 sesame seeds - $1.00 bean sprouts - $1.79 roasted seaweed snack - $0.89 ramen - $0.33 Total is $5.30 Cook your ramen to desired cookness, add in that delicious msg after draining most of the water. While the ramen is cooking, boil eggs for 10 minutes. I put in my eggs in cold water and wait for that to boil up. Add salt to the water. Then decorate with bean sprouts, seaweed, and sesame seeds, placing your eggs on top. Boom.  edit: other substitute add ins would be bok choy, bacon, and beef broth.

My Ramen recipe (for when I donâ€™t eat my Korean ramen)  - Use chicken ramen and cook it normally, leaving the packet to the side - put your seasoning packet in a bowl while the noodles cook - add soy sauce, hot sauce (your choice, I use Sriracha) Cayenne, garlic powder, paprika, parsley, and basil to the bowl - put your noodles (WITH THE WATER ONG) in the bowl and mix it up - put shredded cheddar cheese on top and melt in the microwave  (I never use exact measurements, you will just feel it in your soul)

Try this:  1.Ramen (Udon noodles if you can afford them)...thank me later. I like some soup with mine so i keep some of the water. 2. 1/2 the included seasoning pack 3. A bit of Soy sauce  4. Ginger POWDER (not too much) 5.  Honey/ sugar (not too much) 6. chicken or meat of choice(& a soft boiled egg if you want) 7. Sriracha for a kick Each of these items can be found for under $2 -$3 and last pretty long. This is just a quick mix. (Adjust to your liking of course) Not too boring. Not too extra. my ramen for anyone who wants to try something new  i stole it from my brother and i do really like it  ingredients  2 eggs 1 pack of ramen green onion  a few broccoli florets  instructions  boil water in medium size pot put in the ramen noodles and throw in the eggs as well stir the eggs in with the ramen once fully cooked, put some of the water into the bowl and soak the broccoli a bit if you want it to be aesthetically pleasing take out the broccoli, put in the noodles, stir in the seasoning packet and then put the broccoli on top, if not just do it all except for the broccoli part. finally, cut some green onion, and add spices/ hot sauce to your liking boom egg drop ramen  cheap, protein packed, nutritional(ish), and really good :D

TLDR : cheese,eggs,and carrots are bomb in ramen,all together ot seperate from eachother Experiment with your food people that's how we got all teh things we love today :)         I've been messing with my ramen used to do just ramen and add some no salt seasoning and some garlic powder (very basic) but i loved it,but now i've been trying eggs and that is so good depending on how much you like eggs i'd say stick to 1-2,and also i've tried cheese,you can mix the eggs with cheese and that works very well too because the cheese just melts down completely and just makes the broth more creamy and adds nice flavor and we all know cheese mixes well with eggs and eggs absorb flavour very well so you will notice your ramen is hella flavored,and i've tried carrots in the ramen give the carrots a little time first i also throw in a little extra of the above seasoning into season the carrots just a bit (yes you can micro carrots and they come out and taste the exact same as boiled carrots because you're just boiling them in a microwave) but when they are almost done to your liking then add your ramen and seasoning and any extra you add,the carrots make it so much more airy and make it feel just a bit more healthy (depends if you care but yeah) i wanna try jalepenos soon with it to add a nice kick to things and as much as i love soy sauce and a good hot sauce i never buy it i always forget about it and then when i get home i'm like "omg i'll put some soy sauce in and here and this'll taste so fu**ing good...where's my soy sauce?...omfg i forgot it" needa get some sesame seed and sesame oil aswell and wanna try different veggies with it,i assume many will work because ramen is such a flexible type of food but gotta try it with my own tastes in mind

Never been to college but I know how to budget a bit. Prices do vary according to location but I live in ohio so I'm going with what I find. Single pack maruchan ramen goes for about .18-.25 cents and it goes for all flavors, so you have variety but let's stick to chicken ramen at .22 cents. Canned corn and canned peas go for about .40-.50 cents and you dont use the whole can for one portion. Split it into fourths so one portion would be about .10-.13 cents. Canned mushrooms are optional but go for about 1 dollar, split it into four and it's about .25 cents per portion. The most expensive thing is the protein in this case chicken. A 3lbs bag of raw frozen tenders go for about 7.50-8 dollars. But you only need 1-2 pieces with is about 4oz on average. That is about 12 portions per bag and about .67 cents per portion. So for one meal you are spending around 1.27 each. As a grocery list you will spend a total of about $14-17 before taxes because you will need 12 packs of ramen, 3 cans each of corn and peas, 3 cans of mushrooms optional, and a 3lbs bag of frozen chicken tenders.

The instant ramen hack that will change your life is sesame oil. SESAME OIL! If you prefer it as a stir-fry, stir-fry it in sesame oil. You prefer a nice broth, add sesame oil. Want to add some onion or other veggies? Sautee them in sesame oil before adding your water and noodles. It elevates the "struggle" ramen to "look ma, I'm an adult" ramen. Also, if you really broke then all you have is an egg, no shrimp/chicken. But don't sleep on the egg. Fry it/Boil it and watch it transform your noodles into ramen. ğŸ¤£

Nigeria
Me, an asian: How tf do you mess this up so badly. It's just,,,,noodles,,,and water,,,,,  If you're a poor college student with ramen, I'ma just say this- add eggs. Just crack em in there (after letting the noodles boil and soften), and let them boil until the white cooks, and there is a solid membrane around the yolk. Although it depends on preference-- I like a more liquid yolk, so I only cook it til I feel the membrane. If you cook it too long you won't have a liquid yolk. And yes you will know if you have a liquid yolk in the membrane, bc it will be still squishy when poked with a spoon.  This will make your ramen taste a lot better imo. You can also add beef, pork, or chicken as well.

Iâ€™m 14, hereâ€™s my ramen recipe:  Cut up carrots and green onions and put them in the pot and wait until it boils Then when it starts boiling add the ramen Cook a fried egg (or scrambled) When the ramen is done boiling keep it in for another minute, then itâ€™ll become kind of â€œjellyâ€ like sticky Then pour out some of the water but donâ€™t DROWN the ramen in the water only keep a little bit of water Then heat a skillet and pour a little bit of oil on it and wait until it heats Then put the ramen on the pan and itâ€™ll fry lightly (try not to put the boiled carrots in it, you can but the chopped green onions on it tho) Then you can add the chicken flavour (the packet, you can use the beef or spicy packet too) whatever ramen flavour you chose Then add whatever else spices you prefer example: cayenne pepper, chilli powder, sriracha(etc) I usually add only the chicken flavour packet The voila you got my ramen I made when I was 11 :D

okay here's mine which isn't super out there.  Ramen packet (whichever brand you prefer) cook it - drain most of the water out add season (1/2 to start you can always add the rest) siracha (as much as you like) vinegar and sugar but I use a ketchup packet to substitute (it works man) soy sauce onion powder ( real sauteed if you can)  cayenne  paprika   bam struggle dorm food for CHEAP  edit: this does make it more of noodles in sauce rather than soup but sometimes that's the vibe, do it whichever way you like

All these ramen dishes dry af. This how I cook mine.  These assume you know the basics. You got to season the water that the noodles are being cooked in and I use seasoning salt black pepper and a little bit of garlic powder. I'd say around a teaspoon. Of course you got to use the olive oil so they don't stick and once that's done drain the noodles, but leave a little bit of water because its going to get soaked up over time and the noodles won't be dry and once you're about to use the packet to season it,  season it and stir it in small amounts to cover all the areas.

full proof ramen recipe:Â   1. lightly, like a tiny tiny pinch - season the water with salt  2. cook noodles until al dente, drain most of the water but leave enough for the noodles to have room to float (about 1 cup, maybe 2)Â   3. add the seasoning pack (you don't have to use it all, I usually use half-ish but I'm just being mindful of sodium)Â   4. add 1/4 tsp butter or less, 1/4 tsp sriracha (or more if you need spice in your life)  5. mix them up and the broth should be slightly coloured from the sriracha, very appetizing when food has colour! (more to come)   6. thinly slice green onion (see more colour) and sprinkle on top, shake on some sesame seeds and seaweed flakes. And ~voila~Â   that's just good on its own, or a building base for added mushrooms, bacon, egg, pork belly, cheese etc. And the best part?? ITS CHEAP, you can be broke and eat good! Hereâ€™s how I make my ramen. *what you need* - 2 pots (one small and one medium) -2 eggs -water  *how to cook it* - start by adding the water into the pots and bring it to a boil.  -as the water is going to a boil take two eggs and separate the egg whites from egg yolks (DO NOT BREAK THE YOLKS)  -once the water in boiling in the medium pot I add the seasoning the ramen came with and cook it down.   -once it is cooked down I add the egg whites into the ramen with out draining the water (add it little by little so it doesnâ€™t clump up)  -in the small pot add your egg yolks and let the outside of them become a light yellow but make sure the inside of them are still runny.  -take your ramen with the cooked egg whites and strain it (the seasoning should be cooked into the noodles)  -put the ramen into a bowl and top it with the egg yolks. You can add more seasoning like chili powder if you want. Experiment a little and see what you like.  -I like to pop the egg yolks and mix it in but you can eat it alone.

How to make awesome ramen: 1 cook the noodles according to instructions (boil water and cook noodles for ~3 mins) 2 while the ramen is cooking, add the seasoning packet as well as some pepper to your bowl and mix around a little 3 when your ramen is done add the noodles only to your bowl along with about 1-2 tablespoons of butter and cover until the butter melts (butter should be room temperature) 4 the water, that you cooked your noodles in, over your now buttered noodles until it covers about half of the noodles and mix completely so that all the seasoning thatâ€™s currently on the bottom is now happily seasoning all the noodles 5 enjoy your noodles ğŸ

A "broke college" friend of mine made a very good Ramen Bowl, and it's even healthy. The ingredients are noodles with alfredo sauce, steak seasoned with salt, black pepper, and garlic powder (cooked to medium), chicken seasoned with salt, black pepper, and paprika, shrimp with some seafood seasoning, and he just threw in some avocado slices and mixed them all up in a bowl. Here is how I make mine.  Ingredients : garlic, onion, green onion, chili flakes, brown sugar, msg (any of these are optional but not the garlic. Feel free to add any seasonings you prefer. I sometimes use a little bit of the prepacked seasoning.) Sauce : oyster and soy sauce (It is very easy to make it salty be careful.)  1. Soak the ramen in hot water. 2. Sautee the garlic and onion or any vegetable you have in some oil and caramelize them with the brown sugar  (cooking the ramen will not take long. Use trial and error until you get your veges to perfect doneness.)  3. Add the sauce and let it evaporate for a bit then put in the ramen. 4. Add in the other ingredients until its cooked.  This will get you a dry stir-fried ramen. If you want it more saucy, either omit step 1 and add some water along with the ramen in step 3 or just add a little lesser amount of the hot water from step 1 during step 3(If left soaking in hot water for too long, the ramen will get mushy very fast while cooking). Not the best, not the worst(at least for me). If you enjoy it let me know :)

Do this if you want tasteful ramen everytime without having to add anything extra. All you have to do is add the seasoning last over the noodles (make sure the water isn't covering them) and then leave it there for a minute or two. The noodles will soak up tbe seasoning so you taste it in every bite. Instead of just flavored water with bland noodles.

The two first ain't no Ramen, thats some broke ass Tsukemen without side broth ğŸ’€ And to everyone saying that it tastes better without water, bull shit. That way it just tastes of straight up sodium and heart failure.  If anyone wanna know how to make Ramen with instant noodles, then this is my preferred method: 1. To a bowl, add the seasoning pack, the oil, some MSG and if you want, a bit of soy sauce (japanese or chinese don't really matter, just a little does the trick.) 2. Boil the water, more than you'd usually use, where doing this closer to the traditional way. 3. Add maybe a cup to a cup and a half of the boiling water into the bowl(small bowl half full). Yes where doing this before cooking the noodles, this way we don't get all that nasty starchy water. 4. If you want an egg, put that in, depending on your noodles, cook time may vary but total for the egg is 8 minutes so just add the noodles when the time remaining is right. 5. When the timer sounds, put the egg in a glass of cold water, dump the noodles in a strainer, run a bit of cold water through them to stop them from overcooking, no-one likes soggy noodles. 6. Shake off the noodles, transfer to the bowl being careful not to splash the broth everywhere. Peel the egg and cut lengthwise and put it on top. Add cut scallions if you want. And serve.  Itadakimasu. ğŸ™

I can tell yâ€™all my recipe on how I make my ramen noodles. Itâ€™s a Chinese hot oil inspired recipe.  Noodles:  I heat up water until it starts to boil and then I put the ramen noodles in only and I get rid of the seasoning packet because I donâ€™t use it at all. I then let it cook for exactly 3 minutes and I drain out the water. This is to not have soggy noodles because Iâ€™m looking for almost like a chow mein texture.  Hot oil: I heat up oil (any oil other than olive oil) and I heat up a few spoonfulls of chili flakes (add more for more kick) I then add some pepper and some powdered ginger and some chicken seasoning. I then add half a spoonful of garlic. When that is finished cooking let it cool down and once itâ€™s cooled I add a little bit of sesame oil.   Back to the noodles I place in a bowl and mix in a bit of soy sauce and oyster sauce. I then add the hot oil and I make sure I have the sesame oil added to it. Adjust any ingredients to your liking. Add chicken or shrimp if you like.  If you try this let me know what you think in the comments.

Y do they dump the water out
You find a bowl, aite? You break your ramen in half depending on how big the bowl is and then throw it in the bowl, you with me? Cool, then you add enough water till that shit floats or enough to cover it, might not always float. From there you throw it in a good powered microwave for exactly 3 minutes, take it out, add your seasoning, stir it up GOOD , then throw it back in the wave and let it marinate. DO NOT DUMP THE WATER OUT until AFTER you let it marinate, you gotta let the noodles absorb the juice. Personally, I never drained the water but if you're boujee like that and you don't wanna get your chin wet, go ahead. If you do decide to leave the water in, when you finish the noodles, you drink that shit... DON'T START WHAT YOU CAN'T FINISH! , okay cool. That's how you make ramen noodles.

Easy, cheap ramen recipe I do at home.  1 ramen pack 1Â½ cup water Cheese of choice Egg Ranch powder Desired seasonings Bring water to a high boil in a small pot and place noodles in. Cook and stir occasionally for 3:00 minutes. On the side get a pan, spray with oil or butter and make a sunny side up. After 3 minute is up add your ramen packet into the pot and stir for 10-15 seconds or until noodles are well incorporated and shiny. Dump them into a bowl, add shredded cheese of choice, I prefer colby jack, add your egg on the on top and sprinkle ranch powder on top as a garnish. Enjoy!

Best way to cook ramen packets;  Cook ramen(boil water or cook in microwave). When ramen is done, strain MOST of the water in the ramen, add butter and  1/2 seasoning. Mix well.
